articles.title: How 1Password Used esbuild to Cut Browser Extension Build Times
articles.description: 1Password is a popular password management tool that relies upon a browser extension to fill out passwords on the Web. At over a minute for a single build, things were starting to drag for the devs. Could esbuild help? A fun story with plenty of technical details.
articles.author: Jarek Samic

articles.title: Next.js 15 Release Candidate
articles.description: The popular React meta framework gets ready for a major new release with a RC giving you an opportunity to experiment with React 19 (and React Compiler) support, executing code after a response with next/after, and a few potentially breaking changes.
articles.author: Delba de Oliveira and Zack Tanner

articles.title: aem1k: A Variety of JS Hacks and Creative Coding
articles.description: This is a fun one. Martin really captures the joy and expressiveness of JavaScript and the Web with his collection of projects, whether it‚Äôs offering a NSFW-named tool to convert your JavaScript into just six characters, rendering a spinning globe in 1KB of JS, the Game of Life in 176 bytes, and many more such experiments.
articles.author: Martin Kleppe

articles.title: 10 Modern Node.js Runtime Features to Start Using in 2024
articles.description: If it ever feels like the new feature spotlight shines too much on Bun or Deno, never fear - Node.js has been taking huge strides forward too. Liran looks at lots of what‚Äôs new.
articles.author: Liran Tal

articles.title: ECMAScript 2023 Feature: Symbols as WeakMap keys
articles.description: Dr. Axel continues his look at language features by explaining what WeakMaps are for and why using symbols for keys has added benefits.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†uBlock Origin: Let's Read the Code
articles.description: A prolific code reader spends some time digging into the popular ad blocker that‚Äôs almost entirely built in JavaScript.
articles.author: Ants Are Everywhere

articles.title: Why We Need a Standard JavaScript ORM for SQL Databases
articles.description: ..and is it Drizzle?
articles.author: Paul Scanlon (The New Stack)

articles.title: Want Out of React Complexity? Try Vue
articles.description: A high level piece that may provide some context if you haven‚Äôt dabbled with Vue yet.
articles.author: Richard MacManus (The New Stack)

articles.title: Regexper: Display JavaScript Regular Expressions as Railroad¬†Diagrams
articles.description: Might come in handy for learning regular expressions or if you have a complex regular expression and you don‚Äôt know what it does (not an uncommon situation..!)
articles.author: Jeff Avallone

articles.title: Hono 4.4: The Standards-Based JS Web App Framework for Everywhere
articles.description: Hono is a small, fast web framework with a straightforward API, middleware support, and that runs pretty much on anything (Deno, Bun, Node, Cloudflare, and more). v4.4 brings it to JSR, adds timeout middleware, and a helper to get information about connected clients.
articles.author: Yusuke Wada and Contributors

articles.title: Inertia.js 1.1: Build SPAs for Any Backend
articles.description: Inertia acts as ‚Äòglue‚Äô between various frontend libraries (React, Vue, or Svelte, say) and server-side frameworks (e.g. Rails or Laravel).
articles.author: Jonathan Reinink

articles.title: ShareDB 5.0: Realtime Database Backend Based on Operational Transformation
articles.description: For when you need real time synchronization of JSON documents (such as for behind a real time collaboration app).
articles.author: ShareJS

articles.title: Qlock: A JavaScript Quine Clock
articles.description: We linked to Martin's array of creative JavaScript experiments earlier, but why not finish with one that particularly tickled us? A quine is a program that takes no input but manages to produce, as output, its own source code. Here‚Äôs a fun JavaScript example that isn‚Äôt merely a quine, but a clock too.
articles.author: Martin Kleppe

articles.description: The folks behind the long standing Gulp build tool are running a survey to help make Gulp better and suit modern needs. It closes tomorrow.
ü´† JavaScript's creator Brendan Eich popped up on Twitter/X to refute a claim that JS is "the most slop" by saying it's only 50% so.. I don't get it either.
If you haven't gone down the JSR rabbit hole yet, let ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Ryan Dahl convince you through his DevWorld 2024 talk. (29 minutes.)
Three.js introduces its own 'TSL' shader language as a way to write WebGPU shaders with JavaScript rather than the WebGPU Shading Language.
Astro 4.9 ‚Äì The framework that does everything now does even more, gaining React 19 enhancements, plus a Container API for rendering Astro components outside of Astro apps.
Node.js v18.20.3 (LTS) and v20.14.0 (LTS).
Rspack 0.7 ‚Äì Fast Rust-based web bundler.
Storybook 8.1 ‚Äì The frontend component workshop.
Deno 1.44

articles.title: Old Dogs, New CSS Tricks?
articles.description: We might be in the middle of a CSS renaissance, but with low uptake of many modern features, Max questions if 'feature fatigue' is setting in. He also considers what we can do to ensure uptake of these nice new features and how to fit them into our thought processes.
articles.author: Max B√∂ck

articles.title: üìä¬†Here‚Äôs What We Learned From the First State of HTML Survey
articles.description: A helpful recap of the key findings from the State of HTML survey results ‚Äî a survey that over 20,000 of you filled out.
articles.author: Sacha Greif

articles.title: Modern CSS Layouts: You Might Not Need a Framework For That
articles.description: Various modern CSS features now offer simpler and more flexible approaches to styling and layout, without the added dependencies or abstractions that a framework may introduce. As such, Brecht is keen to encourage confidence in using CSS for those things that we tend to avoid doing ourselves.
articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte

articles.title: A Comprehensive Guide to JS Performance Analysis with Chrome¬†DevTools
articles.description: A surprisingly thorough walkthrough of the practicalities of using Chrome DevTools for digging into performance issues.
articles.author: Jiayi Hu

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†‚ÄúAct on Press‚Äù - John Carmack's Hot Take on UI
articles.description: A video response to a recent, lengthy tweet from John Carmack (of Quake and Armadillo Aerospace fame) on user interface interaction responsiveness. Theo says: ‚ÄúonMouseDown might be my goto in the future‚Äù. Lots of debate on the right approach.
articles.author: Theo Browne

articles.title: Masonry and Reading Order
articles.description: There‚Äôs been plenty of debate lately around so-called masonry layouts, and Rachel (of the Chrome team) wants to address some additional questions around it, specifically on the content reordering issue that masonry presents.
articles.author: Rachel Andrew

articles.title: City in a Bottle: Raycasting in 256 Bytes of HTML and CSS
articles.description: Frank has a reputation for putting together stunning visual demos with the tiniest amounts of code. This is no exception. He goes into a lot of detail about how it works here. Who needs megabytes?
articles.author: Frank Force

articles.title: /¬†Slash Pages: A Guide to Common Base-Level Web Site Pages
articles.description: Some suggestions for what pages (such as /about, /contact, /sitemap, etc.) you may want to consider adding to your site.
articles.author: Robb Knight

articles.title: Stop Resizing Your Browser: Improve Testing for Responsiveness
articles.description: ‚ÄúWhen you resize your browser, you‚Äôre not testing for responsiveness. You‚Äôre testing the side effect of how a layout looks when you resize a browser.‚Äù
articles.author: jen chan

articles.title: Modern WordPress - Yikes?
articles.description: Sharing some frustrations on the current state of WordPress and the ‚Äòcode-within-code‚Äô inception found within the codebase. ‚ÄúI loathe what WordPress development has become‚Äù.
articles.author: David Bushell

articles.title: Fontsource: 1700+ Open Source Fonts in npm Packages
articles.description: On the surface, it‚Äôs a handy way to browse and filter over a thousand different Web fonts (from Google Fonts as well as other sources), but go a step further and you can integrate fonts into your apps in a version-locked manner by way of npm (or just grab a ZIP, if you prefer).
articles.author: Fontsource

articles.title: Signature Pad 5.0: Smooth Signature Drawing for the Web
articles.description: If you need people to give you their signature or similar scrawls on the Web, you can use this to let them scribble away easily. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Szymon Nowak

articles.title: selectlist-polyfill: Polyfill for the Proposed <selectlist>¬†Element
articles.description: Based on a proposal from Open UI, seen here, this polyfill (which depends on the Popover API) aims to overcome the styling and interoperability problems inherent in using the <select> element.
articles.author: Wesley Luyten

articles.title: jessquery: A Lightweight jQuery Alternative for the Modern Web
articles.description: Aims to provide a similar experience to using jQuery by offering a wrapper around the DOM API for easier DOM manipulation at a fraction of the size. It‚Äôs well-documented and works with TypeScript.
articles.author: Jesse Pence

articles.title: Bau.js: A Small, Reactive Library and Components for Building User Interfaces
articles.description: You can check out the 50+ styleable components here, and the library itself boasts no JSX, no templating, no virtual DOM, a CSS-in-JS solution, integration with Astro, among other features.
articles.author: GruCloud

articles.title: OKLCH Color Variations
articles.description: A neat Figma plugin for creating accessible color palettes using the OKLCH color space.
articles.author: Abhishek Y

articles.title: CodeMender: A Platform to Help Frontend Devs Master the Art of¬†Debugging
articles.description: Includes a small collection of free and premium real-world JavaScript project bugs of varying difficulty levels, to help you sharpen your debugging skills.
articles.author: CodeMender

articles.title: Super CSS Mario
articles.description: A slightly wobbly but CSS-only keyboard game in which Mario has to collect some coins whilst avoiding Goombas ‚Äì the usual story. It‚Äôs a Chromium-only experiment, so won‚Äôt work in Firefox or Safari. (If you're on a non-Chromium browser, here's another Mario flavored visualization to play with.)
articles.author: Temani Afif Codepen
